title: Skyscape
statementHtml:
You are given a permutation aa of length nn∗∗.

We say that a permutation bb of length nn is good if the two permutations aa and bb can become the same after performing the following operation at most nn times (possibly zero):

You are also given a permutation cc of length nn where some elements are missing and represented by 00.

You need to find a good permutation b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn such that bb can be formed by filling in the missing elements of cc (i.e., for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, if ci≠0ci≠0, then bi=cibi=ci). If it is impossible, output −1−1.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤5⋅1052≤n≤5⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n). It is guaranteed that aa is a permutation of length nn.

The third line of each test case contains nn integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn (0≤ci≤n0≤ci≤n). It is guaranteed that the elements of cc that are not 00 are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1055⋅105.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case:

  • If it is impossible to find such a good permutation bb, output a single integer −1−1.
  • Otherwise, output nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn — the good permutation bb you've found. You need to ensure that for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, if ci≠0ci≠0, then bi=cibi=ci. If there are multiple answers, output any of them.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, b=[1,2]b=[1,2] is a valid answer since after performing the following operation, aa and bb will become the same:

  • Choose l=1,r=2l=1,r=2 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a1,a2][a1,a2] one position to the right. Then aa will become [1,2][1,2].

In the second test case, b=[2,3,4,1]b=[2,3,4,1] is a valid answer since after performing the following operation, aa and bb will become the same:

  • Choose l=1,r=2l=1,r=2 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a1,a2][a1,a2] one position to the right. Then aa will become [2,3,4,1][2,3,4,1].

In the third test case, b=[1,3,2,4,5]b=[1,3,2,4,5] is a valid answer since after performing the following operation, aa and bb will become the same:

  • Choose l=1,r=3l=1,r=3 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a1,a2,a3][a1,a2,a3] one position to the right. Then aa will become [1,3,2,5,4][1,3,2,5,4].
  • Choose l=4,r=5l=4,r=5 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a4,a5][a4,a5] one position to the right. Then aa will become [1,3,2,4,5][1,3,2,4,5].

In the fourth test case, b=[3,2,1,5,4]b=[3,2,1,5,4] is a valid answer since aa and bb are already the same.

In the fifth test case, it is impossible to find such a good permutation bb, so you should output −1−1.

In the sixth test case, b=[3,2,1,5,4,6]b=[3,2,1,5,4,6] is a valid answer since after performing the following operation, aa and bb will become the same:

  • Choose l=2,r=4l=2,r=4 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a2,a3,a4][a2,a3,a4] one position to the right. Then aa will become [3,2,5,6,1,4][3,2,5,6,1,4].
  • Choose l=3,r=5l=3,r=5 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a3,a4,a5][a3,a4,a5] one position to the right. Then aa will become [3,2,1,5,6,4][3,2,1,5,6,4].
  • Choose l=5,r=6l=5,r=6 and cyclically shift the subsegment [a5,a6][a5,a6] one position to the right. Then aa will become [3,2,1,5,4,6][3,2,1,5,4,6].
tutorialHtml:
A permutation b is considered good if and only if the ordered pairs in a remain ordered pairs in b. In other words, for any pair i<j, if the position of i in a is smaller than that of j, then the position of i in b must also be smaller than that of j.

  • Proof of necessity: The operation will not turn any originally ordered pair in a into an inversion.
  • Proof of sufficiency: For a and b that satisfy the above condition, it is always possible to make a identical to b through the following operation:
    • Iterate over i=1,2,…,n. If ai=bi, skip; otherwise, let j be the position of bi in a, and perform an operation with l=i,r=j.

For numbers in c that are not 0, if they violate the above condition, then it is clearly impossible to find a solution. Otherwise, for a number x that does not appear in c, if we only consider the restrictions imposed by the numbers in c, the legal range for its position in c is an interval [lx,rx]. lx and rx can be calculated using a Fenwick Tree or Segment Tree.

It seems that this is a classic greedy problem of "filling numbers into positions, where the i-th number's position must be within the interval [li,ri]." The approach is to determine each position from left to right. For the i-th position, fill the smallest number j such that lj≤i and rj is the minimum over all numbers j that have not been filled yet. This can be implemented with a heap.

However, we must also consider the mutual constraints between the numbers to be placed in c.

In fact, we can observe that for any x<y, if x's position in a is smaller than y's position, then lx≤ly and rx≤ry. Therefore, if we directly apply the above greedy approach (when multiple rj's are the smallest, fill the smallest j), the legality condition will naturally be satisfied.

Time complexity: O(nlogn) per test case.
